content: CBS was clearly looking for a fresh start when it replaced theMemogate-tainted

tag: html body text div div div p strong span
html body text div div div p span

content: as president of its news division. But unfortunately theappointment seems to have brought McManus a tawdry blast from his own past. Wehear a mentally unstable former bra model who once had a one-night encounterwith McManus—and whom the exec had arrested after she threatened to tellthe press—recently went on a rampage after hearing about hispromotion.

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: The sordid affair began when McManus, at the time V.P. for CBS Sports, wentto an Upper East Side bar on the night of the 1997 U.S. Open and met

tag: html body text div div div p strong span
html body text div div div p span
content: , a then 46-year-old part-time prostitute andformer bra model once known for having “the most beautiful breasts in theworld”—at least according to famed flack

tag: html body text div div div p strong span
html body text div div div p span
content: .The exec reportedly enjoyed a few rounds of cocktails with the buxom blonde, then invited her back to his Park Avenue apartment for a nightcap.

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: It was at this point that their memories of the evening diverge. Von Vogt hasclaimed that she and McManus embarked on a night of drinking, drug use, andkinky sex. In court, an attorney for McManus categorized the whole encountersimply as “a chat, a walk, a drink, [and] a simple and chastegoodbye.” The one thing that’s certain is that after the two parted,von Vogt began to call McManus nonstop, demanding that he acknowledge what sheclaims transpired between them and pleading with him to attend a session withher psychiatrist. When she finally threatened him in February1998­­—after 15 fruitless calls, many of which McManus secretlyrecorded—that she would go public with her story if he persisted indenying what ocurred, he had her arrested for harassment and“telephone stalking.” (McManus, incidentally, had just gottenmarried the previous June.)

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: When the case went to court in 1999, McManus was cross-examined twice aboutthe evening in front of a press-filled gallery. (So much for keeping it out ofthe papers.) Von Vogt, however, suffered a nervous breakdown during theproceedings—brought on, she claimed, by the investigatorsCBS had sicced on her—and the judge declared her unfit for trial.Afterwards, her attorney,

tag: html body text div div div p strong span
html body text div div div p span
content: , suggested shesee a new therapist to deal with the emotional fallout from the case.

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: According to a source close to the trial, von Vogt only saw the therapistbriefly before dropping out of sight—until October of this year, whenMcManus was announced as the incoming CBS News head. We’re told she began calling the female shrink nonstop, venting her anger over the exec’s promotion and claiming “she was going to use [the psychiatrist] to get toMcManus.” Then, last Halloween, von Vogt followed the shrink fromher office and attempted to push her into oncoming traffic on York Avenue and75th Street in Manhattan, screaming, “You Bitch! You piece of garbage! You’rejust a pawn to get to McManus!” She was arrested and, last we heard, was beingheld without bail.

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: McManus could not be reached by presstime.

content: In the course of writing this column, we receive our fare share of verbose legal threats and understand how annoying it can be to deal with the petulant demands of high-powered attorneys. That said, we’re a bit disappointed to see our good pals at Page Six not only cave under pressure, but pass the buck on to us for their own erroneous reporting. In a

tag: html body text div div div p a span
html body text div div div p span
content: , the usually on-target scandal sheet apologized profusely for picking up

tag: html body text div div div p a span

tag: html body text div div div p span

html body text div div div p span
content: is the best-paid lawyer in Hollywood. Decidedly un-kosher, however, is the assertion that we attributed the split to a certain declasse episode at a Hollywood party. We didn’t. The drug and caiter-waiter-banging-bonanza-of-a-blind item in question appeared in

tag: html body text div div div p b span

content: and was subsequently dissected by the readers of

tag: html body text div div div p a span

content: . Although we did link to the item and the Defamer post, we never claimed the anonymous skank was Murphy; only that it didn’t reflect well on her image that a large number of her fans seemed to think it was. In Page Six’s defense, when they get something wrong—as they

tag: html body text div div div p a span
content: reliably do with our site address

content: While New York’s finest chase reporter-turned-“Fire Fiend”

tag: html body text div div div p strong span
html body text div div div p span
content: from strip club to strip club across the Midwest, we hear the depraved journo’s victim has been trying to wrest herself free from the latest crime story to grip the local tabs. Sources say a number of the city’s news outlets have recently received legal letters from

tag: html body text div div div p strong span
html body text div div div p span
content: , a high-powered attorney—and partner at pitbull entertainment lawyer

tag: html body text div div div p strong span
html body text div div div p span
html body text div div div p em span
html body text div div div p span
content: mag staffer has hired to keep her personal details out of the press.

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: Though Goldman would not specify which publications have been contacted, she confirmed that she was retained “to encourage the media to behave in a responsible manner so that this victim isn’t victimized further.” The former

tag: html body text div div div p em span
html body text div div div p span
content: staffer—whose identity, while known in media circles, has been kept out of print—has been keeping a low profile since the Halloween attack, when Braunstein, a onetime co-worker at the fashion glossy, reportedly gained access to her Chelsea apartment by masquerading as a fireman, knocked her out with chloroform, and tied her to a chair before sexually molesting her for 12 hours.

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: “I’ve been dealing with some issues because we’re very concerned about her privacy while this guy is still at large,” said Goldman. “It’s obviously very disturbing that he’s still out there and that he’s evaded the authorities for all this time, so any kind of identifying information that could lead him or other people to locate her is a major invasion of privacy that could put her life in jeopardy.”

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: Among the published details she finds particularly worrisome are where the victim works, where she lives, and even the name of her next-door neighbor, the attorney said. “And that’s not an inclusive list,” she added.

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: While some have speculated that the victim hired a lawyer to keep her own identity under wraps until she is prepared to go public in some remunerative fashion, Goldman insists that’s not the case. “I wasn’t retained because she’s working on a book or movie or any nonsense like that,” she said. “I was retained because she was concerned, as anyone would be in her circumstance, about her privacy and her safety.” She added, however, that her client might be interested in telling her side of the story “somewhere down the road when this guy is incarcerated.”

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: Goldman—who explained she was chosen to represent her client because the two women “share a mutual friend”—said although she herself relies on newspaper reports for developments in the case, she is frustrated by how much info the media-savvy Braunstein might be gleaning from the coverage.

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: “Some of the reporting I’ve seen just seems to me incredibly irresponsible,” she said. “If I’m reading a report in the press of somebody saying, ‘We just saw him at x location going to all these strip clubs,’ don’t you think that he reads the papers and says, ‘Oh, guess I better not go to any more strip clubs?’” Asked whether she had considered the possibility that police had planted those stories to flush Braunstein out, Goldman admitted, “I don’t know what law enforcement does during these situations, but as a citizen reading this stuff, it just strikes me as foolish.”

tag: html body text div div div p span
html body text div div div p a span
html body text div div div h3 a span
html body text div div div p span
html body text div div div p strong span
html body text div div div p span
content: has gotten away with her vindictive tantrums in the past, but sources say she may have chosen the wrong foe in her former PR director,

tag: html body text div div div p strong span
html body text div div div p span
content: . Friends of the well-liked publicist say he hired an attorney to look into a possible libel suit after Regan dispatched a minion to smear him in the

tag: html body text div div div p em span
html body text div div div p span
html body text div div div p span
content: “Paul’s lawyer and his friends are all urging him to sue Regan and [Regan Books parent company] HarperCollins for defamation of character, slander, libel, whatever, for what they said about him in the

tag: html body text div div div p em span
html body text div div div p span
content: ,” says a source close to Crichton, referring to last Wednesday’s Page Six item in which

tag: html body text div div div p strong span
html body text div div div p span
content: —identified as “Regan Media’s interim PR director”—accused the publicist of clearing his desk “at like midnight” and sneaking away after being questioned about “unauthorized spending in his department.”

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: “It was all a lie—he was never under investigation for anything,” says the source. (HarperCollins reps declined to comment on a departing employee, but a company source confirmed to the

tag: html body text div div div p em span
html body text div div div p span
content: ’s Lowdown column that there was never an investigation.)

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: Furthermore, a top-level Regan Books employee said she didn’t know anything about Conway or an “interim PR director.” According to our source, that’s because “Paula is really just a freelance publicist who happens to be a close personal friend of

tag: html body text div div div p strong span
html body text div div div p span
content: , Judith’s sister.” The two women are also co-authors of a book called

tag: html body text div div div p em span
content: The Beauty Buyble: The Top 100 Beauty Products of 2006

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: , scheduled to be published by Regan’s imprint next year.

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: The real reason Crichton decided to leave—after shepherding 13 of Regan’s books onto the

tag: html body text div div div p em span
html body text div div div p span
content: best-seller list—was that his boss was working him like a Siberian husky in the Iditarod, says our source. We’re told that the slight, 32-year-old publicist lost 10 pounds after taking on the responsibilities of associate publisher and director of marketing, in addition to his regular duties, when those positions were vacated in July.

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: “Paul worked his ass off, but Judith was insisting that he sign a three-year contract at the same pay he was receiving before he took on the additional jobs and, on top of that, move to L.A.,” where Regan recently moved her operations, the source says. “When he called her to say he wouldn’t sign and to give notice, she hung up on him. Anyway, you can’t blame him for not looking forward to working with

tag: html body text div div div p strong span
html body text div div div p span
html body text div div div p strong span
html body text div div div p span
html body text div div div p strong span
html body text div div div p span
content: —all of whom have books coming out next year.”

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: But while rumors have been circulating that Crichton may want to vent some of his frustrations by writing a tell-all detailing his ex-boss’s mean streak and infamous private exploits (like her ill-fated affair with wannabe Homeland Security czar

tag: html body text div div div p strong span
html body text div div div p span
html body text div div div p em span
html body text div div div p span
content: ) the publicist’s pal laughs the notion off, saying, “he’s no

tag: html body text div div div p strong span
html body text div div div p span
content: .” Another former Regan Books employee, Clark is already hard at work on a

tag: html body text div div div p em span
html body text div div div p span
content: about the company—in which staffers are thinly disguised to skirt her confidentiality agreement, entitled

tag: html body text div div div p em span
html body text div div div p span
content: . Besides, Crichton may not have much time for writing. We’re told he’s starting a new job next Monday.

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: Crichton himself could not be reached for comment, and calls to a Regan Books publicist were not returned by press time.

tag: html body text div div div p span
html body text div div div p a span
html body text div div div h3 a span
content: Locklear and Sambora: Livin’ on a Prayer?

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: While no one was surprised to learn of

tag: html body text div div div p strong span
html body text div div div p span
html body text div div div p strong span
html body text div div div p span
content: ’s split last week, we hear music biz insiders are buzzing about the possible marital troubles of another, less-stage-managed Hollywood couple—

tag: html body text div div div p strong span
html body text div div div p span
html body text div div div p strong span
html body text div div div p span
html body text div div div p span
content: Long admired for sustaining one of the arena-rock world’s most stable marriages—their eleventh anniversary is later this month—the couple recently fell out over Sambora’s desire to give their 8-year-old daughter,

tag: html body text div div div p strong span
html body text div div div p span
content: , a sibling, according to a source close to the band. We’re told the 44-year-old Locklear, who frequently complains about movie execs’ disdain for aging actresses, thinks a second child would hurt her chances at landing the sexy roles she specializes in.

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: “She doesn’t want another kid because she thinks she’s Hollywood royalty,” says our source. “But Richie is an only child and desperately wants another kid.”

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: Another strain on the couple is the fact that Sambora has just embarked on a seven-month, 20-country world tour with Bon Jovi to promote their new album

tag: html body text div div div p i span
html body text div div div p span
content: —and we’re told the band is doing everything they can to convince him to “dump [Locklear] and move on.”

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: “The members of the band never liked her anyway, particularly Jon [Bon Jovi],” says the source. “The band’s a bunch of blue-collar stiffs from New Jersey who feel that they got lucky. They’re regular guys, and Heather is spoiled—she still thinks that’s she’s an ingénue.”

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: But Sambora isn’t the only one looking for a way out, we hear. According to our source, Locklear has been “stepping out” on her husband.

tag: html body text div div div p span
html body text div div div p i span
html body text div div div p span
content: actress has been spotted with frequently in recent months is her ex-husband, Mötley Crüe drummer

tag: html body text div div div p strong span
html body text div div div p span
html body text div div div p i span
html body text div div div p span
content: ’s Page Six reported, Locklear invited the tattoo-festooned sex-tape auteur back to her place with six female friends after celebrating her birthday at a Manhattan restaurant in October. Apparently she’s forgiven Lee for his affair with porn star

tag: html body text div div div p strong span
html body text div div div p span
content: , the incident that ended their marriage of seven years in 1993.

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: Asked about the marital issues, a spokeswoman for Locklear and Sambora said, “There is absolutely no truth to any of this. They are fine.”

tag: html body text div div div p span
html body text div div div p a span
html body text div div div h3 a span
content: Ahnold’s Foggy Recall in London Libel Case

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: Californians may not be happy with the lack of transparency in the Governator’s office, but none of

tag: html body text div div div p b span
html body text div div div p span
content: ’s political dodges quite compare to his slipperiness in dealing with

tag: html body text div div div p b span
html body text div div div p span
content: , a British TV personality who is suing him for libel.

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: Richardson first became a thorn in Schwarzenegger’s beefy flank when she was quoted in various news stories—including a landmark

tag: html body text div div div p i span
html body text div div div p span
content: magazine article headlined “Arnold the Barbarian”—saying that the actor had pulled her onto his lap and pinched her nipple after a December 2000 interview for her London-based show

tag: html body text div div div p i span
html body text div div div p span
content: . When Schwarzenegger’s team attacked her in an October 2003

tag: html body text div div div p i span
html body text div div div p span
content: story about the then-candidate’s wandering hands—claiming that she’d hopped on his lap, seductively cupped her breasts and asked, “What do you think of these?”—the 35-year-old vicar’s daughter filed a libel suit against the governor and two of his associates.

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: Since then, we hear, the governor and his lawyer,

tag: html body text div div div p b span
html body text div div div p span
content: , have tried every lowdown trick in the book to weasel out of the lawsuit—even going so far as to refuse to accept the service of legal papers for nearly a year, according to a source close to Richardson. (We’re told Singer only relented after her barrister,

tag: html body text div div div p b span
html body text div div div p span
content: , sent him at least three personal letters demanding that he take the case seriously.)

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: Schwarzenegger has also tried to distance himself from the suit, saying

tag: html body text div div div p b span
html body text div div div p span
content: (the Columbia Tristar flack quoted in the

tag: html body text div div div p em span
html body text div div div p span
content: story, now a member of the governor’s communications team) and

tag: html body text div div div p b span
html body text div div div p span
content: (a former campaign spokesman, now director of the state Office of Planning and Research) were not acting with his knowledge or at his behest when they disseminated the slur. Our source says that, in papers filed in his defense, the governor has even denied any official connection to “Californians for Schwarzenegger,” the nonprofit reelection committee that is paying the trio’s legal fees. If that’s the case, the governor may want to refresh his memory. According to municipal documents, Schwarzenegger owns Main Street Plaza, the Santa Monica building that houses the committee’s headquarters.

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: In another curious passage in his defense papers, we’re told that Schwarzenegger “denies that he has a history of sexual misconduct… and the Claimant must prove the grounds on which she alleges that any such history is now admitted or well-documented or was at the time of his election campaign a matter of public knowledge.” While the governor may somehow be under the impression that Brits can’t read American publications, which have obsessively covered Arnold’s multiple groping allegations, the governor’s own admission that “where there’s smoke, there’s fire” and that he’s “behaved badly” towards women have been trumpeted by a dozen UK papers as well.

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: At least Richardson is having it easier than

tag: html body text div div div p b span
html body text div div div p span
content: . After the former stuntwoman announced the day before Schwarzenegger’s election that he had grabbed her breasts, Walsh told reporters that Miller had a history of prostitution and drug abuse. Though the allegations were completely untrue, Miller’s suit was overturned in court thanks to America’s defendant-friendly libel laws. (Luckily for Richardson, Brit law puts the burden of proof on the defense in such cases.)

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: At the end of the day, Schwarzenegger’s maneuvers will probably come to naught. Ever since a judge declared the governor was “not peripheral” to the case, experts have predicted that a settlement is the only way for Schwarzenegger to avoid an inconvenient appearance before a judge in a powdered wig—probably during his 2006 reelection campaign.

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: Reached for comment, Singer declined to discuss his defense strategy—”I’m not an English attorney, but I’ve been told that you’re not supposed to comment on papers filed”—but denied that he or Schwarzenegger had resisted being served. “We resisted

tag: html body text div div div p em span
html body text div div div p span
content: ,” Singer said. “That’s why the papers weren’t accepted, per se. When the process server came to the office, it was voluntarily accepted. There was no evasion of service.” The high-priced attorney did confirm that there had been “numerous communications between me and the plaintiff’s lawyer,” but he wouldn’t go into detail. As for a settlement, “we haven’t discussed it,” he said, adding, for good measure, “You’re a tabloid reporter, and these are stupid questions.”

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: A spokesman for the governor could not be reached by deadline.

tag: html body text div div div p span
html body text div div div p a span
html body text div div div h3 a span
html body text div div div p span
html body text div div div p strong span
html body text div div div p span
content: ’s not the only respected journalist to have his objectivity swayed by access to the high and mighty. Sources at

tag: html body text div div div p em span
html body text div div div p span
content: say the mag’s West Coast editor,

tag: html body text div div div p strong span
html body text div div div p span
content: has gotten a little too close to

tag: html body text div div div p strong span
html body text div div div p span
content: , and that his not-so-secret obsession with his number-one source is affecting his coverage.

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: According to insiders at the gossip glossy, the 35-year-old Baker spends a large part of his day on the phone with Paris, and insists on putting a positive spin on anything published about the heiress—much to the consternation of his boss,

tag: html body text div div div p strong span
html body text div div div p span
content: . “I think this goes far beyond a crush,” confides a friend of Hilton’s. “Every time her phone rings, it’s Ken. He calls more than any other guy, even more than her boyfriends.”

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: The relationship has clearly benefited Baker, who is seen as something of a wunderkind in the business for his ability to bring in celebrity exclusives. Since Paris first appeared on the national scene in 2003 with her infrared sex tape,

tag: html body text div div div p em span
html body text div div div p span
content: has broken the lion’s share of Hilton-related scoops—her break-up with

tag: html body text div div div p strong span
html body text div div div p span
content: , her harrowing account of her hacked Sidekick ordeal, and her engagement to

tag: html body text div div div p strong span
html body text div div div p span
html body text div div div p a span
html body text div div div p span
html body text div div div p em span
html body text div div div p span
content: followed up a week later with the

tag: html body text div div div p a span
html body text div div div p span
html body text div div div p span
content: What could the two possibly be talking about? According to a mag insider, “Paris uses Ken to plant negative items about her enemies, like

tag: html body text div div div p strong span
html body text div div div p span
content: .” In fact, one of the memos found on Hilton’s pilfered Sidekick—“tell ken about jess trying to bone JT”—was widely deciphered as a reminder to tell Baker that

tag: html body text div div div p strong span
html body text div div div p span
html body text div div div p strong span
html body text div div div p span
content: . (The phone’s address book, conveniently enough, contained Baker’s digits, too.)

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: Even in public, Baker has made little attempt to conceal his admiration for his prize canary: he once told Fox News’

tag: html body text div div div p strong span
html body text div div div p span
content: , “When it comes to Paris Hilton, you either love her, loathe her, or lust after her, but either way … you have to admit she’s fascinating,” and even based a character on her—the inventively named London Marriott—in his new satirical roman a clef,

tag: html body text div div div p em span
html body text div div div p span
html body text div div div p span
content: Sadly, the feeling apparently isn’t mutual: “Paris thinks it’s funny when he calls, and will sometimes taunt and even abuse him,” says Hilton’s pal. “She brags that he’s obsessed with her and wants to fuck her.” That’s gratitude for you.

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: Asked about his special friendship with the hotel heiress, Baker played down his role in bringing home the Hilton bacon and denied there was any “quid pro quo” involved. “Paris has chosen to give exclusive interviews to

tag: html body text div div div p i span
html body text div div div p span
content: on several occasions because, I would imagine, she realizes our young readership is her fan base,” he said.

tag: html body text div div div p span
html body text div div div p i span
html body text div div div p span
content: has covered several major news events concerning Paris Hilton with aggressive journalism. For example, we were the only magazine to run a cover on her Sidekick scandal and, most recently, we broke news that Paris had ‘stolen’

tag: html body text div div div p b span
html body text div div div p span
content: ’s boyfriend. I’d imagine Paris would have prefered these stories weren’t given so much coverage, but as a news magazine that is our responsibility to our readers.”

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: Baker went on to say that the idea Paris toyed with him on the phone was a “fiction,” adding that he hadn’t interviewed her in over a month. “If you hear from her, tell her I said ‘Hi!’”

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: We tried to, but Hilton’s crisis manager,

tag: html body text div div div p b span
html body text div div div p span
content: , did not return calls or e-mails, and her publicist, PMK’s

tag: html body text div div div p b span
html body text div div div p span
content: , was “traveling” and could not be reached.

tag: html body text div div div p b span
html body text div div div p a span
html body text div div div p a span
html body text div div div p span
html body text div div div h3 a span
html body text div div div p span
html body text div div div p strong span
html body text div div div p span
content: ’s high-profile bad behavior has broughther international acclaim, her father

tag: html body text div div div p strong span
html body text div div div p span
content: seems to lack the Midas touch of turning personal obnoxiousness into celebritygold. According to a source who spotted the reality show

tag: html body text div div div p em span
html body text div div div p span
content: at the Cartier flagship store in Manhattan Monday afternoon, Hilton left patronsand staff there appalled at his bad manners.

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: “I was sitting next to him on the sofa, and he had this very arrogantposture, with his ankle over his knee and his arm slung over his chair while hetalked loudly on his cell phone,” says our source, who was waiting to pickup a watch. “I knew I knew him from somewhere, and then a young woman[from Cartier] approached him, saying, ‘Hilton! Hilton! Mr. Hilton!’He didn’t move, he didn’t acknowledge anybody, he just kept gabbingon his cell phone, saying, ‘I don’t know why I kept this watch, Iliked the other one I had.’ Yap, yap, yap.”

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: We’re told that when customers complained and asked the clerk if theycould be helped while the flush-faced 50-year-old hotel heir chatted away onhis phone, “She said, ‘Oh, I have to take care of Mr. Hilton,’and kind of rolled her eyes.” Visibly annoyed, the clerk called out,“Mr. Hilton!” and he closed his phone and “went up to takecare of whatever business he had to take care of.”

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: As soon as Hilton left, the clerk turned to our source and cracked, “Ohwell, I guess you can’t buy class.”

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: Called for comment, an employee at the Cartier store on Fifth Avenue and 52ndStreet said she did not recall the incident. Hilton could not be reached bypress time.

tag: html body text div div div p span
html body text div div div p a span
html body text div div div h3 a span
html body text div div div p span
html body text div div div p strong span
html body text div div div p a span
html body text div div div p span
html body text div div div p strong span
html body text div div div p span
content: , but we hear that the filmmaker was once very useful to the King of Pop—thanks, in part, to his highly placed contact within the White House.

tag: html body text div div div p span
html body text div div div p a span
html body text div div div p a em span
html body text div div div p span
content: in which the singer declares, “I love you, Marc. I really need you to get $7 million for me as soon as possible”—is seeking $3 million in loans to Jackson that remain unpaid. But not long ago he was loyally working as the gloved one’s business partner and producer on both his disastrous 2001 album

tag: html body text div div div p i span
html body text div div div p span
content: and a 9/11 tribute concert Jackson planned to hold in Washington D.C. Jacko watchers may also recall Schaffel’s star turn as an

tag: html body text div div div p a span
html body text div div div p span
content: in the singer’s most recent round of pedophilia allegations.

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: It was for the 9/11 tribute project that Schaffel (who, under the

tag: html body text div div div p i span
html body text div div div p span
content: “Marc Fredericks,” has directed over 400 gay porn titles including

tag: html body text div div div p em span
content: The Man With the Golden Rod

tag: html body text div div div p span
html body text div div div p em span
html body text div div div p span
html body text div div div p strong span
html body text div div div p span
html body text div div div p strong span
html body text div div div p span
content: and the deputy director of the Office of Faith-Based and Community Initiatives.

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: Jackson’s script featured a little boy holding the hand of an older man on the steps of the Lincoln Memorial while 50 pop stars, including

tag: html body text div div div p b span
html body text div div div p span
html body text div div div p b span
html body text div div div p span
content: , sang the treacly song in the shadow of America’s 16th president. There was just one snag: in the wake of the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, Washington’s memorial sites were closed or heavily secured. According to

tag: html body text div div div p b span
html body text div div div p span
html body text div div div p i span
html body text div div div p span
content: producer enlisted to work on the video for Jackson’s tribute, Kuo was the team’s “man in the White House.”

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: Despite the lockdown, Jackson and Schaffel were cleared to make the video at the site. “Representatives of the Parks Service said that the go ahead for us to use the Lincoln Memorial had come straight from the White House,” Becker recalls, adding that Jackson returned Kuo’s favor by providing backstage passes to a concert at RFK Stadium in D.C., and that the presidential adviser then “invited members of my staff to the concert and had them over to the White House mess hall for lunches.”

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: In the end, the project was scuttled after Schaffel’s XXX-rated resume became public. Becker says he lost $120,000 of his own money that he had invested in the filming, expecting to be reimbursed.

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: “When it came out that Schaffel was in gay porn and that Jackson had some serious legal problems, Kuo tried to act like he never knew them,” Becker said. “It would have been laughable if I hadn’t been taken for all that money.”

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: Reached for comment, Kuo acknowledged that he had met with both Schaffel and Jackson about the tribute—”I met with hundreds of people a week at the White House”—but denied that he had helped gain them access to the Lincoln Memorial. “After 9/11 the White House was tasked with reaching out to people from the charitable world and Jackson had gotten in touch with us about some song that he was doing just like he had done ‘We are the World,’” Kuo said. “I didn’t have a relationship with either guy, and I never invited staff on the project to come eat lunch at the cafeteria.”

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: Kuo claims that concert promoter Clear Channel, not Jackson, provided his backstage passes to the RFK concert. And his opinion of Jackson? “I met him for a few minutes,” Kuo said, “and I had no particular reaction.” Kuo insisted that as far as he knew, no pedophilia charges had been brought against Jackson at the time.

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: Kuo has since stepped down from the Office of Faith-Based and Community Initiatives to take a contributing editor position at

tag: html body text div div div p a span
html body text div div div p span
html body text div div div p a span
html body text div div div p span
content: on the administration for not doing enough for religious groups (“There was minimal senior White House commitment to the faith-based agenda,” he wrote). A spokeswoman for the office did not return calls by press time.

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: Photos: ABC and Time Warner Boookmark

tag: html body text div div div h3 a span
content: Is Bubba Hedging His Bets For ‘08?

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: Though the pundits have all but ordained her as the Democrats’ next presidential nominee, it hasn’t been all smooth sailing for Sen.

tag: html body text div div div p b span
html body text div div div p span
content: . Publicly at least, the junior Senator from New York still insists she hasn’t made up her mind about a presidential run. But while her coy denials and growing war chest have kept many Democratic opponents on the sidelines, at least one party poobah has not been shy about checking out her competition. Sources close to the Democratic National Committee claim that

tag: html body text div div div p b span
html body text div div div p span
content: has recently held a series of secret meetings with Virginia Gov.

tag: html body text div div div p b span
html body text div div div p span
content: , a much-hyped party moderate who is rapidly emerging as his wife’s most significant challenger for the Democratic nomination.

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: The affable, press-friendly Warner recently sealed his star status in the party after engineering the election of his lieutenant governor,

tag: html body text div div div p b span
html body text div div div p span
content: , to take his place in the governor’s mansion, handing the Dems one of their most significant electoral victories in traditionally red-state Virginia earlier this month. Sources say the former president has grown enamored of Warner, a detail-oriented policy wonk who, like Clinton, rose to prominence as the moderate governor of a conservative Southern state.

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: Even as she fights off competition from the right, Hillary has other problems to worry about. As a host of prospective opponents, including senators

tag: html body text div div div p b span
html body text div div div p span
html body text div div div p b span
html body text div div div p span
html body text div div div p b span
html body text div div div p span
content: , have lined up to demand a swift departure from Iraq, Mrs. Clinton’s stay-the-course message has eroded her support among the party’s progressives. Furious over her refusal to join a growing chorus of Democratic voices calling for an immediate withdrawal, a few leading party doves are accusing the former first lady of putting politics before principle in an effort to cultivate New York’s Jewish vote.

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: “I think a lot of Democrats were surprised when she said that we should stay in Iraq at least through the December Iraqi elections,” says one high-level party insider. “But you can’t win New York State without the support of the state’s pro-Israel Jewish community.” While pundits claim that Democrat contendors historically need two thirds of the Jewish vote in New York to win a Senate campaign, Clinton received a mere 53 percent in her 2000 run against

tag: html body text div div div p b span
html body text div div div p span
content: —a scare she presumably doesn’t want to see repeated.

tag: html body text div div div p span
content: But the senator’s supporters dismiss this charge as “ridiculous,” pointing out that polls show that the state’s Jewish community is as divided about the war as the general electrorate is. “It’s just race baiting,” claims an aggreived Clinton pal who is outraged by the Washington whisper campaign. “Their justified opposition to the war has caused them to adopt the GOP’s worst tactics, but the poll numbers disprove the whole theory.”
